analytic.title: “Dis ‘amen’ à la prière du moine!”: Un cas de récitation interculturelle?

monogr.title: Mélanges de l’Institut dominicain d’études orientales

biblStruct.note: From the origins of Islam to the present day, the issue of the degree of orthodoxy of Christians has tormented generations of Muslims. Yet, the problem of the relationship to be maintained with the clerical authorities of the churches was even more complex, particularly the possible reception of their prayer. This paper is based on an isolated opinion, attributed to a scholar of the Marwānid period (65/685‒132/750) allowing a Muslim “to say ‘amen’ to the invocation (duʿāʾ) of a monk”, while considering that it could not benefit to the later. This opinion was transmitted in a Syrian context, at the end of the Umayyad period, via the great scholar al-Awzāʿī before it was recorded in Ibn Abī Šayba’s ḥadīṯ collection, as well as in two later Sufi treatises. In order to discern, within three generations of scholars of the second century AH, the grounds which were favorable to Christian clerics and that which condemned them, we aim to address them diachronically through the general evolution of the relationship to Christianity and its most charismatic representatives, which from an official pre-Umayyad veneration turned into an Abbasid institutional distrust.
